title: 109_s759
content: The Act titled "Make College Affordable Act of 2005" expands the deduction for higher education expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment sets limitations on the amount allowed as a deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses for taxpayers in any taxable year. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2005" sets limitations on the deduction for higher education expenses. For the taxable year 2005, the deduction is $8,000, and for 2006 and beyond, it is $12,000. The deduction is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income determines the deduction for higher education expenses, with specific thresholds based on income levels. Adjusted gross income thresholds for deductions related to higher education expenses are subject to inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2005. Adjusted gross income thresholds for deductions related to higher education expenses are subject to inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2005. In the calendar year the taxable year begins, the adjustment involves substituting 'calendar year 2004' for 'calendar year 1992' and rounding amounts to the nearest multiple of $50. Additionally, the amendment includes defining eligible students for qualified tuition and related expenses in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The code is amended to redefine eligible students for tax deductions related to higher education expenses. The amendments made are permanent and effective for payments after December 31, 2004. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR INTEREST ON HIGHER EDUCATION LOANS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section allowing for a tax credit on interest paid on higher education loans. A tax credit is allowed for interest paid on qualified education loans by individuals, with a maximum credit of $1,500. The credit amount is reduced if the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeds $50,000 ($100,000 for joint returns). The tax credit for interest on qualified education loans is reduced based on modified adjusted gross income, with a maximum credit of $1,500. The income threshold for reduction is $50,000 for individuals and $100,000 for joint returns, with adjustments for inflation after 2005. The tax credit for interest on qualified education loans is subject to adjustments based on income levels, with a maximum credit of $1,500. The credit is reduced for individuals with a modified adjusted gross income above $50,000 and $100,000 for joint returns, with inflation adjustments after 2005. Additionally, the credit is only allowed for the first 60 months of interest payments on qualified education loans. The tax credit for interest on qualified education loans is limited to the first 60 months of required interest payments. Special rules apply, such as no double benefit allowed and married couples must file a joint return to claim the credit. Tax credit for interest on qualified education loans is only allowed if the taxpayer and their spouse file a joint return. Marital status is determined according to section 7703. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section apply to any qualified education loan incurred before or after the enactment of this Act, but only for loan interest payments due after December 31, 2004.
